tossups.question: The term sphota refers to this action’s invariant essence in Patanjali’s writings. Societies that perform this activity maintain “homeostasis” by “sloughing off memories”, according to a book that claims this activity wells up out of the unconscious into consciousness. A culture characterized by this activity is posited in Eric Havelock’s book Preface to Plato. This activity is paired with literacy in a book by Walter Ong. The claim that Jean-Jacques Rousseau privileged this activity in one of his essays appears in the book Blindness and Insight. A lecture that argues a woman could not engage in this action since she was “marginalised by both the coloniser and colonised” examines her dilemma using the example of sati. An essay by Gayatri Spievak asks if the subaltern can engage in, for 10 points, what activity that Jacques Derrida believed had been given primacy over writing?
tossups.answer: speaking or speech [accept orality from Ong clue of Orality and Literacy]

tossups.question: In one opera, a character requests to participate in this type of event by singing “Digli che in questo petto come puro l'amor, sacra è la fiamma.” The title character of another opera ponders the delayed delivery of a ring before learning of this kind of upcoming event, which prompts his aria “Bagnato il sen di lagrime.” In an English opera, the protagonist sings “I’ve sighted a sail in the storm / the far-shining sail that’s not Fate” the night before one. Percy and Rochefort ask to take part in one of these events in a Donizetti opera. A character watching one of these events mumbles "ancora non ti muovere" after exclaiming “Ecco un artista!” The title character of a Benjamin Britten opera sings “Starry Vere, God bless you” during his one of these events. Due to the treachery of Scarpia, Cavaradossi undergoes a real one in Tosca. For 10 points, name this ultimate fate of the title characters of Roberto Devereux, Anna Bolena, and Billy Budd.
tossups.answer: executions [or being executed; accept being beheaded or being hanged or going before a firing squad; prompt on less specific answers such as killings or death or dying]

tossups.question: When Ike attended the drama Sleep No More, Ike was taken by “the Matron”, given some tea, and then told a story whose exact text was ripped from this play, in which a boy discovers that the Moon is a rotten piece of wood, and the Sun is a wilted sunflower. That “black fairy tale” from this play is told by its character of the Grandmother. This play opens with the title character cutting sugarcanes, insisting that a man once confused a human head that was “rollin along” for a hedgehog, and that three days later he was killed by Freemasons. Sleep No More also copied a scene from this play in which the title character is called “abysmally stupid” while performing his daily shave of a character called the Officer. This unfinished drama in 29 scenes centers on a man who stabs Marie after she sleeps with the “drum major.” For 10 points, name this Georg Buchner play that was adapted into an opera by Alban Berg.
tossups.answer: Woyzeck

tossups.question: The company Haldor Topsoe developed the RKS catalyst for use in this process. Dolomite is used to sequester one of the products of this process in a variant of it that is termed "sorption-enhanced." Oyxgen is added to induce partial oxidation of the reaction mixture in an "autothermal" version of this process. This process can be performed internally in an MCFC or an SOFC. In order to reduce the overall S:C ratio, this process is often followed by an MTS or HTS reactor, followed by pressure swing adsorption to purify the product. The most common catalyst used for this reaction is alumina-supported nickel. The water-gas shift reaction is used to increase the conversion of this reaction, which provides the feedstock for the Haber-Bosch process. For 10 points, name this reaction which combines methane and water to produce carbon monoxide and hydrogen, a mixture called syngas.
tossups.answer: steam reforming [or methane reforming; prompt on reforming; prompt on hydrogen synthesis or any answer suggesting this is the process of making hydrogen or making syngas]

tossups.question: Ronald Bunn’s monograph on this event includes an appendix cataloguing the political orientations of thirty newspapers that responded to it, and mentions how it was exacerbated by the “endkampf” missive. This event was partly caused by accusations that a man had awarded the contracts for military apartment units to the company Fibag. This event occurred after Conrad Ahlers provided information about the “Fallex 62” maneuver, exposing a country’s navy and airforce as woefully ill-prepared to respond to a nuclear attack. During this event, Claus Jacobi and Johannes Engel were detained, though they were never brought to trial. It was largely caused by the illegal arrests ordered by Franz Josef Strauss, who targeted the editor Rudolf Augstein. Konrad Adenauer’s chancellorship was damaged by, for 10 points, what political incident named for a West German magazine?
tossups.answer: Der Spiegel Affair

tossups.question: A memoir by this writer describes how his teacher Mrs. K introduced him to the “brutal bargain” of social mobility, exemplified by the “longest journey” from “Brooklyn to Manhattan.” An essay by this writer discusses coming in second at a relay race, only for the opposing team trying to jump him and take their first-prize medallions after it was revealed that the opposing team had cheated. This author called the Cold War the Third World War in a 2007 book arguing that the current fight against “Islamofascism” constitutes World War IV. A 1963 essay by this author of the memoir Making It notes that a certain group was “tougher . . . and more ruthless” than the Jews and Italians in his Brooklyn neighborhood, and explains his hatred of black people. “My Negro Problem—and Ours” was written by, for 10 points, what neoconservative longtime editor of Commentary magazine?
tossups.answer: Norman Podhoretz

tossups.question: The ground state in this formalism can be related to the ground state in a different formalism by the Gell-Mann and Low formula. This formalism is mathematically incompatible with a relativistic quantum field theory according to Haag's theorem. Analysis of the Jaynes-Cummings model involves invoking this formalism, then making the rotating wave approximation. In this formalism, an operator denoted U can be expressed as 1 minus i times a time integral containing U--iteratively solving that equation and introducing the time-ordering operator thus yields an infinite power series solution for the propagator named for Freeman Dyson. In this formalism, the perturbed part of the Hamiltonian is the operator driving the time evolution of the wavefunction. Both the operators and the state vectors have time dependence in, for 10 points, what picture of quantum mechanics which is thus intermediate between the Schrodinger and Heisenberg pictures?
tossups.answer: interaction picture [accept the Dirac picture; I guess prompt on quantum field theory or qft]

tossups.question: An account claims this conflict began after a murder at Mosquito Reserve led to a peace delegation reported on by Peter Ballantyne. The rejection of a 10-point “Revolutionary Bill of Rights” also sparked this conflict, during which “Gentleman” Joe McKay killed two commanders at Duck Lake. A leader of one side was named for his ability to lure buffalos into traps known as pounds – that leader, Poundmaker, traveled to Fort Battleford as chief of the Cree people in this conflict, but his tribesman Big Bear was tracked down at its end by General Sam Steele. A steamer dubbed The Northcote failed to run the gauntlet and Frederick Middleton forced the surrender of Gabriel Dumont at the Battle of Batoche in this uprising. Its instigator was hanged despite resistance from Wilfrid Laurier. For 10 points, name this 1885 rebellion led by Louis Riel and the Metis which took place after the Red River Rebellion.
tossups.answer: North-West Rebellion of 1885 [or Saskatchewan Rebellion; accept Second Riel Rebellion before mentioned]

tossups.question: According to a “local historian”, one of the first women in charge of this place deliberately contracted smallpox to see which of her lovers, Charles Phelipson or Stephen Reynard, was more faithful. Many years after that incident involving Squire Dornell’s daughter Betty, another woman in this place married Edmund, a man whose face was disfigured in a fire. However, after that woman from here remarries Lord Uplandtowers, she gets a seizure when Uplandstower defaces a statue of Edmund. Two stories from the collection A Group of Noble Dames, including “Barbara of the House of Grebe”, are set in this place. The first so-called “cliffhanger” is set in this place, and centers on Elfride Swancourt and her two suitors: Henry Knight and Stephen Smith. For 10 points, name this fictional region that is the setting of A Pair of Blue Eyes, and The Mayor of Casterbridge.
tossups.answer: Wessex

tossups.question: In a painting by this artist, Oliver Cromwell clasps his hands in prayer while in his tent the night before Naseby. A painting by this artist was inspired by gossip that a certain monarch banned mirrors, and depicts that monarch looking at her emaciated face when using a looking-glass. This artist of Queen Elizabeth Discovers She is No Longer Young included two female children building a house of cards on a novel by Balzac in one of his paintings. Another painting by this artist depicts a woman below the Adelphi Arches gazing at the Moon and is titled Despair. This artist was a member of Richard Dadd’s group called The Clique. The style of William Holman Hunt inspired this artist’s best-known series, which depicts the aftermath of a woman’s adultery and consists of two night scenes, and a day scene intended to be viewed as a triptych. For 10 points, name this painter of the Past and Present series.
tossups.answer: Augustus Egg

tossups.question: Among this tribal group, powers of nature called poha are wielded by religious doctors called pohakanti. It's not Spaniards, but these people gather to make music for days at gatherings called "fandangos". Julian Haynes Steward described the traditional subsistence of this tribal group, which drove antelopes into corrals and trapped jackrabbits in nets in "bands" of 50 or 60. The Te-Moak band and Goshute are subgroups of this people, who sued and were sued by the U.S. government in the Ruby Valley land dispute. Their chieftain Pocatello signed the Treaty of Box Elder after surviving a massacre and making land deals with newly-arrived Mormons. The most famous member of this Great Basin tribal group bore a son named Jean-Baptiste to Toussaint Charbonneau near Fort Mandan in 1805. For 10 points, name these people with reservations in Nevada and Idaho who included Sacagawea.
tossups.answer: Shoshone peoples [or Northern Shoshone; or Eastern Shoshone; or Te-Moak Shoshone; or Goshute Shoshone; or Lemhi Shoshone]

tossups.question: A 1990 paper by Ben-Or and Goldreich proved that if one-way functions exist, then the Computational Zero-Knowledge complexity class equals this other one. Scott Aaronson showed that the existence of closed timelike curves would mean that quantum Turing Machines would have the power of this complexity class. Using an alternating Turing Machine on the set of problems in this class yields EXPTIME. The set of true quantified Boolean Formulas is part of the “complete” variant of this class. This class was initially thought to be smaller than another class, until a man used the graph connectivity problem and the fact that the square of a polynomial is still a polynomial to to show that this class and its nondeterministic counterpart are actually equivalent. For 10 points, name this complexity class, consisting of decision problems that are solvable with a polynomial amount of memory.
tossups.answer: PSPACE [accept IP or Interactive Proof until “quantum”]

tossups.question: One member of this family may have secretly married the Antarctic explorer Elisha Kane, and struggled for 10 years to get his inheritance by showing off his love letters. This family first gained attention by introducing the case of a peddler named Charles B. Rosna. Two members of this family moved to live with Amy and Isaac Post, who penned a book based on their knowledge. They were connected with a series of incidents called the “Hydesville Events,” named for their family cottage, which was discussed in a “History” of a movement started by this family, written by Arthur Conan Doyle. Charles Page exposed the “rapping sounds” supposedly caused by Mr. Splitfoot, but actually coming from under the long dresses of the two youngest girls in this family. For 10 points, name these spiritualist sisters who performed séances for idiots like James Fennimore Cooper.
tossups.answer: Fox Sisters [or Leah, Maggie/Margaret, and Catherine/Kate Fox]

tossups.question: In the article “To Be Done with Depth of Field,” Andre Bazin criticized the “obsolete play” of this technique, arguing that its use inhibited the “dialectical progress . . . of language.” In a pioneering essay in cinemetrics, Barry Salt concluded that claims about how this technique was once dominant were false, finding that it was only used in 30-40% of commercial footage since the 1940s. This technique is likened to both the creation of Israel and the displacement of Palestinians by Jean-Luc Godard in the film Notre Musique. This technique, which is often complemented with various over-the-shoulder interruptions, is often said to be an example of the eyeline match concept. It breaks the 180-degree rule by switching back and forth between images of the faces of two characters. For 10 points, name this editing technique used to depict conversations, and which usually has a three-word name.
tossups.answer: shot/reverse shot or shot/countershot

tossups.question: In a novel by this author Amina denounces the grievances her husband dictates in a secret book after a stroke ruins his career as a painter. Bill Cosby wrote the introduction to an English translation of this author’s nonfiction work inspired by his protests against the Debre Law. The protagonist destroys his diploma in a sink, and resolves to take over his dead father’s fruit cart in a story by him that fictionalizes Mohamed Bouazizi’s self-immolation. A set of novels by this author concerns the sexual awakening of Zahra, the eighth daughter of a man who raises her as a boy named Ahmed to circumvent inheritance law. This author of The Happy Marriage and “By Fire” used a question-and-answer style in his popular book Racism Explained to My Daughter. The Sacred Night and The Sand Child are two Prix-Goncourt-winning novels by, for 10 points, what perennial Nobel favorite from Morocco?
tossups.answer: Tahar Ben Jelloun [prompt on Jalloun]

tossups.question: When this man died of meningitis, a large mausoleum for him was erected at Arno’s Vale Cemetery in Bristol. This man wrote a pamphlet offering “Brief Remarks on Modern Encroachments on the Ancient Rights of Women,” and a series of ethical tracts drawn from the gospels titled Precepts of Jesus, the Guide to Peace and Happiness. This man founded an institution shortly after visiting the Scottish watchmaker David Hare; at that school, a group of radicals known as the “Derozians” flourished. He collaborated with William Carey to help William Bentinck ban a certain practice. This man’s belief that the “unity of the Supreme Being [i]s the Sole Ruler of the universe” is the guiding principle of a group he founded that practiced a monotheistic variant of Hinduism. The Anglo-Hindu School in Calcutta was founded by, for 10 points, what leader of the Brahmo Sabha movement, known as the “father of Modern India”?
tossups.answer: Raja Ram Mohan Roy

tossups.question: This organization created a photomosaic whose individual pictures were taken at the exact moment that many people smiled, as alluded to in its title. The person responsible for that project, Carolyn Porco, helped create another of this organization's photographs, which a 1994 lecture at Cornell insisted was the best "demonstration of the folly of human conceits." Swedish Victor Hasselblad cameras were used by this organization to create a photo that critic Galen Rowell said was the most influential environmental photograph ever produced. In 2012, this organization used a device named after Verner Suomi to make a nighttime image called "The Black Marble," which was a complement to the “Blue Marble” image. The photos "Pale Blue Dot" and "Earthrise" were made by, for 10 points, what government agency, which produced many other images using the Spitzer Space Telescope?
tossups.answer: NASA [or National Aeronautics Space Agency]

tossups.question: Cdc42, Par6, Par3, and one form of this protein come together to form a complex which mediates epithelial cell polarity. This protein is the target of a macrolide isolated from Bugula neritida; that compound is an experimental HIV and Alzheimer's drug and is called bryostatin. MARCKS proteins are substrates of this protein. This protein contains a "pseudosubstrate" sequence which constitutively inhibits its action by binding to its catalytic domain until this protein binds to its allosteric activators. This protein comes in 15 isoforms, divided into 3 families called conventional, novel, and atypical. This protein is translocated to the plasma membrane by RACK proteins after it is activated by di∙acyl∙glycerol. For 10 points, name this family of signalling proteins, which, like a protein named for calmodulin, classically phosphorylate other proteins at serine and threonine residues in a calcium-dependent manner.
tossups.answer: protein kinase C [or PKC]

tossups.question: A man with this surname wrote letters addressed to “Mr. Richards,” signed as “Edward Edwards,” which he allegedly bottled and tied around a box tree. That man of this surname wrote The Natural History of Guiana and the epistolary History of Charles Wentworth after researching in Suriname. Another man of this last name co-wrote a book with John Palfrey, which proposed the four values of progress, patria, providence, and pan-democracy as the founding ideals of America. The first man by this surname may have poisoned Silas Deane, and worked in Paris as a double agent for the British. The second succeeded John Mason as Secretary of the Navy under James K. Polk, wherein he established the US Naval Academy in Annapolis. For 10 points, give this name shared by the colonial spy Edward and George, whose massive 10-volume work led him to be dubbed the “Father of American History.”
tossups.answer: Bancroft [double agent Edward Bancroft and historian George Bancroft]

tossups.question: The man “of venerable robustness” who delivers this address enters carrying no umbrella from a gale and has “melting sleet” on his “tarpaulin hat.” This work’s speaker describes a group of men who offer speculations about a traveler, such as “Jack, he’s robbed a widow” and “Joe, do you mark him, he’s a bigamist.” The man who makes this presentation is described as “impregnable in his little Quebec” while standing in a bower that represents the “earth’s foremost part.” In this address, the speaker tells of a man who paid “thrice the usual sum” for passage since “sin that pays its way can travel freely”. After ascending a ladder and pulling it back up after him, this work’s speaker stands in a pulpit shaped like a ship’s prow to talk about Jonah. The Whaleman’s Chapel is the location of, for 10 points, what religious address listened to by Queequeg and Ishmael?
tossups.answer: “Father Mapple’s Sermon” [prompt on sermon from Moby Dick; prompt on sermon]

bonuses.leadin: At the end of this process, DNA ligase IV is used to create the coding and signal joints. For 10 points each:
answers: V(D)J recombination [or VJ recombination; prompt on recombination]
parts: Name this process, which begins when the protein RAG1 binds to an RSS and makes a double-strand break. The function of this process is similar to that of a related process called somatic hypermutation.

V(D)J recombination is the mechanism which creates diversity in the T-cell receptor and in these proteins, whose heavy chains can change between 5 different isotypes in a process called "class switching."

According to a namesake rule, a recombination signal sequence, or RSS, consists of a conserved heptamer and a nonamer separated by a spacer whose length in number of base pairs is one of these two numbers. Name both.

bonuses.leadin: This speech cites a list of “dreams” that “have been vitalized” by its central subject, including “the dream of jobs for all who seek them...and need them” and “the dream of an all-out attack on mental illness.” For 10 points each:
answers: LBJ’s "Let Us Continue" speech [prompt on LBJ’s first address as president, or his first address to a joint session of congress after the death of JFK]
Teodoro Moscoso [or José Teodoro Moscoso Mora]
parts: Give the three-word common title of this speech, which was drafted in its early form by Ted Sorensen, and begins by declaring “All I have I would have given gladly not to be standing here today.”

In his draft, Sorensen wrote that JFK breathed new spirit into American life despite being in the White House for just a little more than this time period, which would title an autobiography by Arthur Schlesinger.

This Puerto Rican businessman and current namesake of a bridge in San Juan coordinated the Alliance for Progress under JFK, putting into place Operation Bootstrap while serving under Luis Muñoz Marín.

bonuses.leadin: The 13th section of this work features heavy rolled chords in the low bass that are on eighth-note offbeats, while its 22nd section is often compared to a music box. For 10 points each:
answers: Johannes Brahms’s Variations and Fugue on a Theme by Handel [accept Brahms’s Op. 24 or Handel Variations]
Clara Schumann [or Clara Josephine Wieck(-Schumann); prompt on Schumann, do not accept or prompt on “Robert Schumann”]
nocturnes [or notturno; accept Nocturne in F major Op.6 No.2]
parts: Name this 1861 work for solo piano whose theme, which begins with a B-flat quarter note followed by a trilled C, is taken from the third movement aria of a Baroque composer’s Harpsichord Suite in B-flat Major.

Brahms’s Variations and Fugue on a Theme by Handel was dedicated to and premiered by this pianist whose own compositions include the piano collection Soirées musicales, and a well-regarded G minor piano trio.
Clara Schumann’s Soirées musicales includes an F major piece in this style, which she wrote at age 16. Irish pianist John Field is usually credited with inaugurating this genre of piano work.

bonuses.leadin: Michael Walzer devoted a chapter of The Company of Critics to this short book, noting that its English title is invoked conversationally more often than the book is read. For 10 points each:
answers: The Treason of the Intellectuals or Le Trahison de Clercs or The Betrayal of the Intellectuals
parts: Name this 1927 book by Julien Benda, which critiques the title group’s lack of “critical detachment” from politics, and calls for a unified Europe. It condemns the divergent nationalism of title figures like Paul Nizan and Charles Maurras.

On counts of intellectual dishonesty and anti-Semitism, Benda singles out this French nationalist author of The Cult of the Self and The Faith of France. He was an associate of Action Francaise founder Charles Maurras.

Benda’s later book Addresses to the European Nation plays on the title of this author’s Addresses to the German Nation, a work Benda claims was more important to German unification than the Zollverein. This philosopher also wrote Attempt at a Critique of all Revelation.

bonuses.leadin: Gina, who pretends to be the “panther woman of Broadway” and who is actually the orphan Iris Mateluna, “play[s] yumyum” with the owner of this object, which she calls the chonchón. For 10 points each:
answers: the giant’s head [or Don Romualdo’s costume head, or the papier-mache bird head; accept Don Romualdo’s (bird) costume]
parts: Name this object that a character rents for 1500 pesos an hour to assume the identity of a homeless man who lives in the back of the abandoned Ford. It is later donned by Jerónimo de Azcoitía, who exchanges genitals with another character in a scheme to impregnate Iris.
The giant’s head appears in this Chilean writer’s novel The Obscene Bird of Night.
A model named Sylvia has an affair with Anselmo, and uses vanishing cream to make Anselmo’s penis disappear in this novella from Donoso’s Sacred Families Trilogy.

bonuses.leadin: This device was independently invented by the Finnish scientist Yrjo Vaisala, and is used to correct coma and astigmatism in addition to spherical aberrations. For 10 points each:
answers: Schmidt corrector plates [prompt on corrector plates]
parts: Name these aspheric lens that are used in their namesake’s cata∙dioptric telescopes.
Catadioptric telescopes are so named because they combine lenses with these devices.

The Schmidt catadioptric telescopes are the precursor of these telescopes, which uses a secondary mirror to reflect light from the primary mirror into the eyepiece. Hyperbolic mirrors are used in the Ritchey-Chretien variant of these telescopes.

bonuses.leadin: This painting can be found in the Centraal Museum, next to its artist’s Margareta Maria de Roodere and Her Parents. For 10 points each:
answers: Gerrit von Honthorst [or Gerard von Honthorst; accept Gherardo delle Notti]
parts: Name this painting which depicts a man holding a bag of money with his back to the viewer. Its title figure might be the old woman on the left, who may be helping the woman with a lute and man get together.

This Utrecht artist painted The Matchmaker as well as several other works which highlighted his distinct skill in depicting realistic candlelight. This man has made some notable portraits of the Duke of Buckingham as well as Marie de Medici.
Gerrit von Honthorst was a member of this group of painters which venerated the artist of The Calling of Saint Matthew. Another notable member, Georges de la Tour, painted The Penitent Magdalene.

bonuses.leadin: This poet repeats the line “Hymenaon, Sing the wedding song!” in a poem beginning with an exhortation to “Raise high the roof-beam, carpenters! For 10 points each:
parts: Those lines come from H.T. Wharton’s 1895 standard English translation of what classical lyric poet, said by Plutarch to have invented the Mixolydian mode and by some classical writers to have invented the plectrum?

Salvatore Quasimodo updated into “living Italian” the translation of Sappho by this earlier Italian Romantic, whose long poem “Dei Sepolcri” protested Napoleonic prescriptions on the size of and inscriptions on burial monuments.

This author admitted he had “ploughed with Goethe’s cow” in his dramatic treatment of Sappho’s rejection by Phaon and subsequent suicide. Over thirty years later this Austrian wrote the play The Jewess of Toledo.

bonuses.leadin: Name these lion deities who protect people when they’re not eating them, for 10 points each.
answers: Sekhmet [or Sakhmet or Sachmis or Sakhet]
parts: This brother of Humbaba, and son of Hanbi, is the “king of the wind demons” in Mesopotamian myth. Often shown with lion claws and scorpion tail, he chases away the evil child-killing goddess Lamashtu.
This consort of Ptah, the lioness goddess of Egypt, was mollified by Ra’s blood-colored beer and persuaded not to eat all of humanity.

This goofy lion spirit in Indonesian myth is the guardian of the forest of Bali, and the hero of a ritual dance with namesake masks. Men wielding kris swords are whipped into a self-harming trance by the spell of this lion’s eternal rival, the witch Rangda.

bonuses.leadin: The pyrrhic victors at this battle were boxed in by the forces of generals Falckenstein, Goeben, Flies, and Beyer before escaping into a trap in the Harz Mountains, for 10 points each:
answers: Seven Weeks’ War [accept Austro-Prussian, Unification, Prussian-German, Brothers, or Fraternal War]
Gastein Convention [or Bad Gastein, or Treaty of Gastein]
parts: Name this 1866 battle which resulted in the fall of Hanover and its subsequent annexation by Prussia two days later when King George V of Hanover surrendered at Nordhausen.
The Battle of Langensalza took place during this conflict which also saw the success of Garibaldi’s “Hunters of the Alps” at Bezzecca, and Moltke the Elder’s victory at Koniggratz.

This 1865 treaty was created prior to the Seven Weeks’ War to establish the respective rights of Austria and Prussia to the duchies of Schleswig and Holstein, which had just been acquired from Denmark via the Treaty of Vienna.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the architecture and design of luxury brand retail spaces, for 10 points each:
parts: This architect of choice for Dior and Louis Vuitton, and Chanel boutiques, is very visible among both the fashion and architecture communities for his public image of wearing full leather gear.

This Japanese fashion label’s first boutique featured no mannequins or mirrors to emphasize designer Rei Kawakubo’s maxim that one should buy clothes “because of how they make you feel, not how they make you look”.

Herzog & de Meuron designed a transparent boutique for this luxury brand with green glass walls on Tokyo’s Omotesando boulevard. An art installation recreates one of this brand’s storefronts with real handbags and shoes in Marfa, Texas.

bonuses.leadin: The presence of these regions lowers the effective reactor volume. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these "zones" present in a chemical reactor with imperfect mixing, which are regions in the reactor where mixing is low, so no reaction occurs there.

Ideal reactors are operated under this condition, in which the flowrate in equals the flowrate out, and the concentrations of all of the reactive components are constant throughout time. Two-step batch reaction kinetics can be simplified by this approximation, which states that the amount of intermediate remains constant.
The residence time distribution in an ideal plug-flow reactor takes the form of this function.

bonuses.leadin: St. Aretas may have been among the Christians at Najran burned by this ruler, who allegedly committed suicide by riding his horse into the Red Sea. For 10 points each:
answers: Dhu Nuwas [or Yusuf ibn Sharhabeel, or Yousef Athar]
parts: Name this Judaic warlord named for his curly hair, who ruled the Himyarite Kingdom starting around 517 AD.
The Himyarite kingdom ruled over this modern-day country known to the Romans as Arabia Felix. The Sabaeans built the Ghumdan Palance at its walled city of Sana’a.

Refugees from Najran may have reached the court of Justin I, who refused to help them because he was too busy dealing with this schism, which was caused when a namesake Byzantine patriarch under Emperor Zeno issued the Henotikon, leading to a fight with Pope Felix III.

bonuses.leadin: According to a history by Helena Attlee, the mafia first rose to power by practicing extortion, intimidation, and racketeering among the gardens where this crop was grown. For 10 points each:
answers: lemons [or Citrus limon; prompt on citrus]
parts: Name this crop, whose prevalence in and around Palermo led Palermo to be called the “Conca d’Oro.”

Mafia-sponsored lemon farming on Sicily took off with the ascension of this group of people, who took land from aristocrats and rented it out to poorer farmers. This class of people hired campieri to protect equipment and guards, and often became mafia dons.

One reason for the demand of lemon fruit in the 18th and 19th centuries was James Lind’s proof that it could be used to treat this disease. The symptoms of this disease caused by Vitamin-C deficiency include bleeding gums.

bonuses.leadin: According to the original submission on this novella, this book was “written before the discovery of the ABO [blood] system, [and it] ends with a blood transfusion somehow returning a dead maid to life.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novella, in which the narrator Latimer gives a long-winded non-description of how he came to be able to predict aspects of his future, including his own death.
The Lifted Veil is a novella by this Victorian author, whose otherwise realistic fiction includes Daniel Deronda and Adam Bede.

George Eliot’s only historical novel depicts the influence of this character on a woman named Romola. Rioters protesting against this man cause Tito Melema to jump into a river and be killed by Baldassare Calvo.

bonuses.leadin: Cole-Cole plots are used to describe this phenomenon, whose mathematical derivation for an oscillating electric field was derived by Debye. For 10 points each
answers: dielectric relaxation [or dipole relaxation or Debye relaxation]
parts: Name this phenomenon, where the changing the external electric field permeating a material will cause the material's polarization to change, while lagging behind the change in the E-field.
Dielectric relaxation is basically analogous to this process that occurs in ferromagnets, where the magnetization lags behind changes in the magnetic field. When plotted, it produces a namesake loop.
The x-intercept of a ferromagnetic hysteresis loop is known by this term, since it represents the value of the applied magnetic field needed to completely cancel the magnetization in the material.

bonuses.leadin: Dizzy Gillespie most likely played both the trumpet and piano on the original recording of this 1945 song, which has a chord progression based on Ray Noble's song "Cherokee." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Charlie Parker song that shares its name with the Lord High Executioner from The Mikado who has a "little list" and who sings "As some day it may happen."
The original recorded version of Charlie Parker's "Ko-Ko" includes a solo by this leading bebop drummer, who also played the drums on the albums Birth of the Cool and Saxophone Colossus.
Max Roach founded this percussion ensemble, whose debut 1973 album Re: Percussion includes the songs "Jihad Es Mort" and "Onomatopoeia."

bonuses.leadin: One of these works, which is about “selfdiscovery,” claims that the delusions of “past”, “present”, and “future,” of “quote, mankind, unquote” are big enough for “supermechanized submorons,” but too small for one human being. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this set of works that were delivered as part of the Charles Eliot Norton Lectures series. The last of them discusses their author’s morality play Santa Claus, in which Love is deemed a superior force to Science.
i-six nonlectures was written by this poet, who wrote a poem opening “Humanity I Love You,” before concluding “Humanity I hate you.” He also wrote the novel The Enormous Room.
ee cummings’ other misanthropic poems include “Pity this Busy Monster, Manunkind,” which ends with the exhortation to the reader “listen: there’s a hell of a good [this thing] next door; let’s go”.

bonuses.leadin: A 1959 stamp depicts a farmer holding a stack of wheat above his head with two threshers on his left under the text “Hail the Conquerors of” the title location of this program. For 10 points each:
answers: Virgin Lands Campaign [or Tselina or Tselino]
parts: Name this effort to expand wheat production in the steppes of northern Kazakhstan, centered around the city of Akmolinsk, which fell apart by the mid-1960s due to poor land management.

Much of the farming expertise utilized in the Virgin Lands Campaign came from Volga Germans who had been deported by this man, the chief of the NKVD under Stalin. In his memoirs, he claimed to have assassinated Stalin.

Khrushchev pushed for the Virgin Lands Campaign to counter his rival Georgy Malenkov, who conspired with this other member of the Anti-Party Group known as the “Iron Lazar” in an aborted attempt to overthrow Khrushchev. This man is the subject of Stuart Kahan’s biography The Wolf of the Kremlin.

bonuses.leadin: This text opens with a fable about an enormous fish called Kun which transforms into a giant bird called Peng. For 10 points each:
answers: consummate person or exemplary person or genuine person or zhi ren
parts: Name this text, that uses an anecdote about a monkey trainer acceding to the monkeys’ wish to have four acorns in the morning and three in the evening, which the author calls “Walking Two Roads” to illustrate the paradox between heaven and Earth.
Another illustration of Zhuangzi’s perspectivism involves wondering whether he is a man dreaming he is one of these creatures, or one of these creatures dreaming he’s a man.

Zhuangzi refers to this class of people to refer to one who can “master things without harm.” In a dialogue presented in the chapter titled “Equalizing Assessment of Things,” Wang Nie states this type of individual “uses his mind like a mirror,” responding to the world but not “storing” its images.
